awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Negotiating migration adversity and well-being
awd_abstract_narration:
As migrants navigate public places, medical systems, and resettlement efforts in new cities, they often encounter discrimination, inadequate resources, and a lack of institutional services, which have been well-documented to have a syndemic effect with other underlying health issues. This doctoral dissertation research project examines how experiences of adversity relate to resilience and well-being in urban environments, and what resources are leveraged in responding to adversity. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology and biocultural data collection and analysis, this project measures the role that resilience and sentiments of belonging play in influencing experiences of adversity in multicultural and urban environments. The project enhances public understanding of science and the scientific method by engaging its research communities in the scientific research process and broadly disseminating its findings beyond academic venues. It also broadens the participation of underrepresented groups in science.

Using multidisciplinary methods, this project investigates resilience and well-being by examining the behavioral context of migrant decision-making, focusing specifically on how issues related to health, livelihood, and time management are prioritized. This project asks two main questions: 1) how do migrants make sense of and negotiate experiences of adversity? and 2) how do spaces of community both succeed and fail to manage the effects of adversity? Methods include participant observation, semi-structured interviews, focus groups, and mapping workshops to explore the relationship between resilience and adversity. Data will be coded around themes of belonging, histories of migration, experiences of city-life, migration trade-offs, ideas of community, and notions of well-being. By scientifically investigating how migrants negotiate adversity and resilience in their daily lives, this project will contribute to research on community, resilience, and well-being in urban areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project focuses on how community organizations provide social and healthcare services for migrant (and non-migrant) communities to help them negotiate their well-being and quality of life. Over a period of 20 months of fieldwork in Ontario, Canada, this research sought to answer the following questions: 1) How do migrants make sense of their experiences of adversity and draw upon community to do so?; and 2) How do community organizations succeed and/or fail to help migrants manage the effects of adversity? At the beginning of the research project, migrants began discussing their struggles with understanding how to access healthcare support for their family and friends who received life-limiting diagnoses. Many migrants and their families, whether they migrated recently or earlier, described having difficulties navigating the healthcare system when receiving terminal diagnoses and seeking end of life care. Through their recommendations, this project focused on how palliative and hospice community centers were able to provide social and healthcare resources, services, and supports for migrants and their families - using hospice organizations as the community sites to answer the research questions.

This project used ethnographic fieldwork (participant observation, focus groups and in-depth interviews) to learn more about how these organizations help people fulfil a sense of community and navigate adversity within the healthcare system. The results of the research project are as follows.  Hospice organizations fulfill a unique role for migrants in helping them improve their well-being and quality of life, providing complementary care to the biomedical healthcare system. For example, these organizations help address barriers that migrants encounter in the healthcare system by providing culturally-appropriate care, language services, and toolkits as migrants interact with doctors and other healthcare practitioners. Moreover, these organizations provide an array of social and practical supports. The hospice organizes support through volunteers, who visit clients once a week for 4 hours in their homes. Volunteer services are tailored based on the client’s needs and can include practical services, like preparing meals, grocery shopping, light cleaning, driving them to appointments or stores, and also social supports, like spending quiet time in their company, reading a book aloud, and having conversations about their interests. Time between clients and volunteers can also include legacy work, like helping clients craft music playlists, make photo albums, paint, draw, and write autobiographies or letters to be passed down to ttheir loved ones. These hospice and palliative care organizations thus provide a sense of community for migrant (and non-migrant) clients and provide services that address well-being and quality of life that are not often attended to in traditional biomedical care.

This research contributes to the fields of anthropology and medicine by providing important data about how migrants with life-limiting illnesses receive social, practical, and medical support, contributing to our understanding of quality of life, well-being, and resilience during periods of adversity (such as migrant and end-of-life). Moreover, this project contributes to the field of migration by investigating how these organizations provide culturally appropriate services that take into account how adversity and inequality affect access to healthcare. This research will in turn support hospice programming and clinical understanding of quality of life for migrants with life-limiting illnesses. In order to accomplish these goals, reports will be written in the form of toolkits and presentations, outlining the ‘lessons learned’ for hospices and clinicians to understand how community organizations can help address gaps in biomedical care. Moreover, in collaboration with a hospice, we have created an outreach presentation that provides people with knowledge about hospice palliative care: clarifying terminology, providing them with advanced care planning tools, and alerting them to their rights in healthcare settings. The presentation was designed to be understandable for people who speak English as a second language to ensure that people who are underserved and underrepresented in healthcare settings have tools to navigate these complex situations. Additionally, this research trained a doctoral student in cultural and medical anthropology and will contribute to knowledge about migration, well-being, and healthcare access for academic and non-academic audiences.
